21.passage:
I believe it is very true, my dear, indeed," said [MASK], with a sigh. "I am afraid I am sometimes very fanciful and troublesome."

"My dearest papa!

25.passage:
The chances are that she must be a gainer."

"Well," said [MASK], willing to let it pass--"you want to hear about the wedding; and I shall be happy to tell you, for we all behaved charmingly. Every body was punctual, every body in their best looks: not a tear, and hardly a long face to be seen.

36.passage:
I planned the match from that hour; and when such success has blessed me in this instance, dear papa, you cannot think that I shall leave off match-making."

"I do not understand what you mean by 'success,'" said [MASK]. "Success supposes endeavour.

97.passage:
I am sure you always thought me unfit for the office I held."

"Yes," said [MASK], smiling. "You are better placed _here_; very fit for a wife, but not at all for a governess.

118.passage:
I wonder what will become of her!"

"So do I," said [MASK] gently, "very much."

"She always declares she will never marry, which, of course, means just nothing at all.

127.passage:
I have done very little."

"If it were admissible to contradict a lady," said [MASK]

"I have perhaps given her a little more decision of character, have taught her to think on points which had not fallen in her way before."

"Exactly so; that is what principally strikes me.

150.passage:
It is the fault of her face that she has them not."

"Do you think so?" replied [MASK]. "I cannot agree with you.

154.passage:
Exactly so indeed!"

"It is very pretty," said [MASK]. "So prettily done!

177.passage:
You need not be prompted to write with the appearance of sorrow for his disappointment."

"You think I ought to refuse him then," said [MASK], looking down.

"Ought to refuse him!

220.passage:
I am glad you think so; and the good hands, I hope, may not be wanting."

"Come," said [MASK], "you are anxious for a compliment, so I will tell you that you have improved her. You have cured her of her school-girl's giggle; she really does you credit."

"Thank you.

244.passage:
What is the foolish girl about?"

"Oh! to be sure," cried [MASK], "it is always incomprehensible to a man that a woman should ever refuse an offer of marriage. A man always imagines a woman to be ready for any body who asks her."

"Nonsense!

258.passage:
Better be without sense, than misapply it as you do."

"To be sure!" cried [MASK] playfully. "I know _that_ is the feeling of you all.

269.passage:
I shall leave off while I am well."

"Good morning to you,"--said [MASK], rising and walking off abruptly. He was very much vexed.

316.passage:
I shall never let that book go out of my own hands," said she.

"Very well," replied [MASK]; "a most natural feeling; and the longer it lasts, the better I shall be pleased. But here is my father coming: you will not object to my reading the charade to him.

353.passage:
He may be sure of every woman's approbation while he writes with such gallantry."

"I have no hesitation in saying," replied [MASK], though hesitating a good deal while he spoke; "I have no hesitation in saying--at least if my friend feels at all as _I_ do--I have not the smallest doubt that, could he see his little effusion honoured as _I_ see it, (looking at the book again, and replacing it on the table), he would consider it as the proudest moment of his life."

After this speech he was gone as soon as possible.

380.passage:
one can think of nothing else."

"And really, I do not think the impression will soon be over," said [MASK], as she crossed the low hedge, and tottering footstep which ended the narrow, slippery path through the cottage garden, and brought them into the lane again. "I do not think it will," stopping to look once more at all the outward wretchedness of the place, and recall the still greater within.

384.passage:
Well, (smiling,) I hope it may be allowed that if compassion has produced exertion and relief to the sufferers, it has done all that is truly important. If we feel for the wretched, enough to do all we can for them, the rest is empty sympathy, only distressing to ourselves."

[MASK] could just answer, "Oh!

390.passage:
She then broke the lace off short, and dexterously throwing it into a ditch, was presently obliged to entreat them to stop, and acknowledged her inability to put herself to rights so as to be able to walk home in tolerable comfort.

"Part of my lace is gone," said [MASK], "and I do not know how I am to contrive. I really am a most troublesome companion to you both, but I hope I am not often so ill-equipped.

416.passage:
He has not been here yet," replied [MASK]. "There was a strong expectation of his coming soon after the marriage, but it ended in nothing; and I have not heard him mentioned lately."

"But you should tell them of the letter, my dear," said her father.

422.truth: the good - hearted Mrs. John Knightley
422.passage:
'--I remember that perfectly."

"How very pleasing and proper of him!" cried [MASK]. "I have no doubt of his being a most amiable young man.

447.passage:
I am sure it almost killed me once."

"Come, come," cried [MASK], feeling this to be an unsafe subject, "I must beg you not to talk of the sea. It makes me envious and miserable;--I who have never seen it!

530.passage:
Well, sir, the time must come when you will be paid for all this, when you will have little labour and great enjoyment."

"My first enjoyment," replied [MASK], as they passed through the sweep-gate, "will be to find myself safe at Hartfield again."



CHAPTER XIV

563.passage:
He could not be satisfied without a promise--would not she give him her influence in procuring it?"

"So scrupulous for others," [MASK] continued, "and yet so careless for herself! She wanted me to nurse my cold by staying at home to-day, and yet will not promise to avoid the danger of catching an ulcerated sore throat herself.

583.passage:
Every thing that I have said or done, for many weeks past, has been with the sole view of marking my adoration of yourself. You cannot really, seriously, doubt it. No!--(in an accent meant to be insinuating)--I am sure you have seen and understood me."

It would be impossible to say what [MASK] felt, on hearing this--which of all her unpleasant sensations was uppermost.

585.passage:
It confesses that you have long understood me."

"No, sir," cried [MASK], "it confesses no such thing. So far from having long understood you, I have been in a most complete error with respect to your views, till this moment.

606.passage:
'--If he would say so to her at once, in the tone of decision becoming a man, there would be no opposition made to his going."

"No," said [MASK], laughing; "but perhaps there might be some made to his coming back again. Such language for a young man entirely dependent, to use!--Nobody

613.passage:
Had he begun as he ought, there would have been no difficulty now."

"We shall never agree about him," cried [MASK]; "but that is nothing extraordinary. I have not the least idea of his being a weak young man: I feel sure that he is not.

620.passage:
You seem determined to think ill of him."

"Me!--not at all," replied [MASK], rather displeased; "I do not want to think ill of him. I should be as ready to acknowledge his merits as any other man; but I hear of none, except what are merely personal; that he is well-grown and good-looking, with smooth, plausible manners."

"Well, if he have nothing else to recommend him, he will be a treasure at Highbury.

624.passage:
To you, he will talk of farming; to me, of drawing or music; and so on to every body, having that general information on all subjects which will enable him to follow the lead, or take the lead, just as propriety may require, and to speak extremely well on each; that is my idea of him."

"And mine," said [MASK] warmly, "is, that if he turn out any thing like it, he will be the most insufferable fellow breathing! What!

637.passage:
I hope she is well?"

"Thank you. You are so kind!" replied [MASK], while eagerly hunting for the letter.--"Oh! here it is.

666.passage:
I was glad you made her play so much, for having no instrument at her grandmother's, it must have been a real indulgence."

"I am happy you approved," said [MASK], smiling; "but I hope I am not often deficient in what is due to guests at Hartfield."

"No, my dear," said her father instantly; "_that_ I am sure you are not.

679.passage:
I am disappointed," was his only answer.

"I hope every body had a pleasant evening," said [MASK], in his quiet way. "I had.

736.passage:
It was a good scheme; but on driving to the door they heard that neither "master nor mistress was at home;" they had both been out some time; the man believed they were gone to Hartfield.

"This is too bad," cried [MASK], as they turned away. "And now we shall just miss them; too provoking!--I do not know when I have been so disappointed." And she leaned back in the corner, to indulge her murmurs, or to reason them away; probably a little of both--such being the commonest process of a not ill-disposed mind.

749.passage:
She was pleased with the eagerness to arrive which had made him alter his plan, and travel earlier, later, and quicker, that he might gain half a day.

"I told you yesterday," cried [MASK] with exultation, "I told you all that he would be here before the time named. I remembered what I used to do myself.

751.passage:
One cannot creep upon a journey; one cannot help getting on faster than one has planned; and the pleasure of coming in upon one's friends before the look-out begins, is worth a great deal more than any little exertion it needs."

"It is a great pleasure where one can indulge in it," said [MASK], "though there are not many houses that I should presume on so far; but in coming _home_ I felt I might do any thing."

The word _home_ made his father look on him with fresh complacency.

764.passage:
Call upon her, by all means."

"There is no necessity for my calling this morning," said [MASK]; "another day would do as well; but there was that degree of acquaintance at Weymouth which--"

"Oh! go to-day, go to-day. Do not defer it.

799.passage:
I will move a little farther off."

"I certainly do forget to think of _her_," said [MASK], "as having ever been any thing but my friend and my dearest friend."

He looked as if he fully understood and honoured such a sentiment.

802.passage:
Ever hear her!" repeated [MASK]. "You forget how much she belongs to Highbury. I have heard her every year of our lives since we both began. She plays charmingly."

"You think so, do you?--I wanted the opinion of some one who could really judge.

819.passage:
It is a most repulsive quality, indeed," said [MASK]. "Oftentimes very convenient, no doubt, but never pleasing. There is safety in reserve, but no attraction. One cannot love a reserved person."

"Not till the reserve ceases towards oneself; and then the attraction may be the greater.

842.passage:
She had an opportunity now of speaking her approbation while warm from her heart, for he stopped to hand her out.

"This is coming as you should do," said [MASK]; "like a gentleman.--I am quite glad to see you."

He thanked her, observing, "How lucky that we should arrive at the same moment!

922.passage:
That will do," said [MASK], when it was finished, thinking aloud--"you have sung quite enough for one evening--now be quiet."

Another song, however, was soon begged for.

953.passage:
What am I to do?"

"I am here on no business of my own," said [MASK]; "I am only waiting for my friend. She will probably have soon done, and then we shall go home.

965.passage:
No more it is."

"No trouble in the world, ma'am," said [MASK].

"Oh!

1053.passage:
Very true," he gravely replied; "it was very bad." But still he went on measuring, and still [MASK] ended with,

"I think there will be very tolerable room for ten couple."

"No, no," said she, "you are quite unreasonable.

1054.passage:
But still he went on measuring, and still he ended with,

"I think there will be very tolerable room for ten couple."

"No, no," said [MASK], "you are quite unreasonable. It would be dreadful to be standing so close!

1056.passage:
Nothing can be farther from pleasure than to be dancing in a crowd--and a crowd in a little room!"

"There is no denying it," [MASK] replied. "I agree with you exactly.

1089.passage:
To do what would be most generally pleasing must be our object--if one could but tell what that would be."

"Yes, very true," cried [MASK], "very true. You want your neighbours' opinions.

1114.passage:
Happy those, who can remain at Highbury!"

"As you do us such ample justice now," said [MASK], laughing, "I will venture to ask, whether you did not come a little doubtfully at first? Do not we rather surpass your expectations?

1122.passage:
It seemed like the forerunner of something absolutely serious, which she did not wish. Forcing herself to speak, therefore, in the hope of putting it by, [MASK] calmly said,

"You are quite in the right; it was most natural to pay your visit, then"--

He was silent.

1124.passage:
A very few minutes more, however, completed the present trial. [MASK], always alert when business was to be done, and as incapable of procrastinating any evil that was inevitable, as of foreseeing any that was doubtful, said, "It was time to go;" and the young man, though he might and did sigh, could not but agree, to take leave.

"I shall hear about you all," said he; "that is my chief consolation.

1127.passage:
What strength, or what constancy of affection he might be subject to, was another point; but at present she could not doubt his having a decidedly warm admiration, a conscious preference of herself; and this persuasion, joined to all the rest, made her think that she _must_ be a little in love with him, in spite of every previous determination against it.

"I certainly must," said [MASK]. "This sensation of listlessness, weariness, stupidity, this disinclination to sit down and employ myself, this feeling of every thing's being dull and insipid about the house!-- I must be in love; I should be the oddest creature in the world if I were not--for a few weeks at least.

1149.passage:
--there is nothing to surprize one at all.--A pretty fortune; and she came in his way."

"I dare say," returned [MASK], sighing again, "I dare say she was very much attached to him."

"Perhaps she might; but it is not every man's fate to marry the woman who loves him best.

1242.passage:
Dinner-parties and evening-parties were made for him and his lady; and invitations flowed in so fast that she had soon the pleasure of apprehending they were never to have a disengaged day.

"I see how it is," said [MASK]. "I see what a life I am to lead among you.

1247.passage:
I hope you turned directly."

"I went only to the post-office," said [MASK], "and reached home before the rain was much. It is my daily errand.

1256.passage:
I have often thought them the worst of the two," replied [MASK] coolly. "Business, you know, may bring money, but friendship hardly ever does."

"Ah!

1258.passage:
You have every body dearest to you always at hand, I, probably, never shall again; and therefore till I have outlived all my affections, a post-office, I think, must always have power to draw me out, in worse weather than to-day."

"When I talked of your being altered by time, by the progress of years,"  said [MASK], "I meant to imply the change of situation which time usually brings. I consider one as including the other.

1267.passage:
You look as if you would not do such a thing again."

"Oh! she _shall_ _not_ do such a thing again," eagerly rejoined [MASK]. "We will not allow her to do such a thing again:"--and nodding significantly--"there must be some arrangement made, there must indeed.

1275.passage:
If I meet with no insuperable difficulties therefore, consider that point as settled."

"Excuse me," said [MASK] earnestly, "I cannot by any means consent to such an arrangement, so needlessly troublesome to your servant. If the errand were not a pleasure to me, it could be done, as it always is when I am not here, by my grandmama's."

"Oh!

1281.passage:
And when one considers the variety of hands, and of bad hands too, that are to be deciphered, it increases the wonder."

"The clerks grow expert from habit.--They must begin with some quickness of sight and hand, and exercise improves them. If you want any farther explanation," continued [MASK], smiling, "they are paid for it. That is the key to a great deal of capacity.

1283.passage:
The varieties of handwriting were farther talked of, and the usual observations made.

"I have heard it asserted," said [MASK], "that the same sort of handwriting often prevails in a family; and where the same master teaches, it is natural enough. But for that reason, I should imagine the likeness must be chiefly confined to the females, for boys have very little teaching after an early age, and scramble into any hand they can get.

1292.passage:
I do not admire it," said [MASK]. "It is too small--wants strength. It is like a woman's writing."

This was not submitted to by either lady.

1319.passage:
Something that would do!" repeated [MASK]. "Aye, _that_ may suit your humble ideas of yourself;--I know what a modest creature you are; but it will not satisfy your friends to have you taking up with any thing that may offer, any inferior, commonplace situation, in a family not moving in a certain circle, or able to command the elegancies of life."

"You are very obliging; but as to all that, I am very indifferent; it would be no object to me to be with the rich; my mortifications, I think, would only be the greater; I should suffer more from comparison.

1376.passage:
And if they are, I only beg you to send them home."

"No," cried [MASK], "that need not be the consequence. Let them be sent to Donwell.

1378.passage:
I shall certainly be at leisure."

"Upon my word," exclaimed [MASK], "you amuse me! I should like to know how many of all my numerous engagements take place without your being of the party; and why I am to be supposed in danger of wanting leisure to attend to the little boys.

1435.passage:
She hesitated a moment, and then replied, "With you, if you will ask me."

"Will you?" said [MASK], offering his hand.

"Indeed I will.

1441.passage:
I do not want to say more than is necessary--I am too much ashamed of having given way as I have done, and I dare say you understand me."

"Yes," said [MASK], "I hope I do."

"How I could so long a time be fancying myself!

1456.passage:
I am sure I never suspected it, you did it so naturally."

"And so you actually put this piece of court-plaister by for his sake!"  said [MASK], recovering from her state of shame and feeling divided between wonder and amusement.

1462.passage:
But I kept my eye on it; and, as soon as I dared, caught it up, and never parted with it again from that moment."

"I do remember it," cried [MASK]; "I perfectly remember it.--Talking about spruce-beer.--Oh! yes--

1520.passage:
Have you never at any time had reason to think that he admired her, or that she admired him?"

"Never, never!" [MASK] cried with a most open eagerness--"Never, for the twentieth part of a moment, did such an idea occur to me.

1531.passage:
She promised him again and again to come--much oftener than he doubted--and was extremely gratified by such a proof of intimacy, such a distinguishing compliment as she chose to consider it.

"You may depend upon me," said [MASK]. "I certainly will come.

1571.passage:
They were looking over views in Swisserland.

"As soon as my aunt gets well, I shall go abroad," said [MASK]. "I shall never be easy till I have seen some of these places.

1588.passage:
She still intended him for her friend.

"How much I am obliged to you," said [MASK], "for telling me to come to-day!--If it had not been for you, I should certainly have lost all the happiness of this party. I had quite determined to go away again."

"Yes, you were very cross; and I do not know what about, except that you were too late for the best strawberries.

1601.passage:
But (lowering her voice)--nobody speaks except ourselves, and it is rather too much to be talking nonsense for the entertainment of seven silent people."

"I say nothing of which I am ashamed," replied [MASK], with lively impudence. "I saw you first in February.

1615.passage:
Here are seven of you, besides myself, (who, she is pleased to say, am very entertaining already,) and she only demands from each of you either one thing very clever, be it prose or verse, original or repeated--or two things moderately clever--or three things very dull indeed, and she engages to laugh heartily at them all."

"Oh! very well," exclaimed [MASK], "then I need not be uneasy. 'Three things very dull indeed.'

1617.passage:
Three things very dull indeed.' That will just do for me, you know. I shall be sure to say three dull things as soon as ever I open my mouth, shan't I? (looking round with the most good-humoured dependence on every body's assent)--Do not you all think I shall?"

[MASK] could not resist.

1622.passage:
I must make myself very disagreeable, or she would not have said such a thing to an old friend."

"I like your plan," cried [MASK]. "Agreed, agreed.

1629.passage:
I doubt its being very clever myself," said [MASK]. "It is too much a matter of fact, but here it is.--What two letters of the alphabet are there, that express perfection?"

"What two letters!--express perfection!

1634.passage:
_Perfection_ should not have come quite so soon."

"Oh! for myself, I protest I must be excused," said [MASK]; "_I_ really cannot attempt--I am not at all fond of the sort of thing. I had an acrostic once sent to me upon my own name, which I was not at all pleased with.

1642.truth: Miss Fairfax , who had seldom spoken
1642.passage:
[MASK] before, except among her own confederates, spoke now.

"Such things do occur, undoubtedly."--She was stopped by a cough.

1658.passage:
I wish you could have heard her honouring your forbearance, in being able to pay her such attentions, as she was for ever receiving from yourself and your father, when her society must be so irksome."

"Oh!" cried [MASK], "I know there is not a better creature in the world: but you must allow, that what is good and what is ridiculous are most unfortunately blended in her."

"They are blended," said he, "I acknowledge; and, were she prosperous, I could allow much for the occasional prevalence of the ridiculous over the good.

1701.passage: What is to become of that?--Very true. [MASK] was talking of it just now.--'You must go,' said she. 'You and I must part.

1702.passage: You and I must part. You will have no business here.--Let it stay, however,' said she; 'give it houseroom till [MASK] comes back. I shall talk about it to him; he will settle for me; he will help me out of all my difficulties.

1703.passage:
I shall talk about it to him; he will settle for me; he will help me out of all my difficulties.'--And to this day, I do believe, she knows not whether it was his present or his daughter's."

Now [MASK] was obliged to think of the pianoforte; and the remembrance of all her former fanciful and unfair conjectures was so little pleasing, that she soon allowed herself to believe her visit had been long enough; and, with a repetition of every thing that she could venture to say of the good wishes which she really felt, took leave.

1776.passage:
He positively said that it had been known to no being in the world but their two selves."

"Well," said [MASK], "I suppose we shall gradually grow reconciled to the idea, and I wish them very happy. But I shall always think it a very abominable sort of proceeding.

1837.passage:
Poor girl!" said [MASK]. "She thinks herself wrong, then, for having consented to a private engagement?"

"Wrong!

1844.passage:
Yes, I have no doubt of her being extremely attached to him."

"I am afraid," returned [MASK], sighing, "that I must often have contributed to make her unhappy."

"On your side, my love, it was very innocently done.

1847.passage: But she probably had something of that in her thoughts, when alluding to the misunderstandings which he had given us hints of before. One natural consequence of the evil she had involved herself in," [MASK] said, "was that of making her _unreasonable_. The consciousness of having done amiss, had exposed her to a thousand inquietudes, and made her captious and irritable to a degree that must have been--that had been--hard for him to bear. 'I did not make the allowances,' said she, 'which I ought to have done, for his temper and spirits--his delightful spirits, and that gaiety, that playfulness of disposition, which, under any other circumstances, would, I am sure, have been as constantly bewitching to me, as they were at first.'

1866.passage: Her arm was pressed again, as [MASK] added, in a more broken and subdued accent, "The feelings of the warmest friendship--Indignation--Abominable scoundrel!"--And in a louder, steadier tone, he concluded with, "He will soon be gone. They will soon be in Yorkshire.

1885.passage:
Oh! then, don't speak it, don't speak it," [MASK] eagerly cried. "Take a little time, consider, do not commit yourself."

"Thank you," said he, in an accent of deep mortification, and not another syllable followed.

1891.passage:
I will tell you exactly what I think."

"As a friend!"--repeated [MASK], that I fear is a word--No, I have no wish--

1905.passage:
We will not be severe."

"It will be natural for me," [MASK] added shortly afterwards, "to speak my opinion aloud as I read. By doing it, I shall feel that I am near you.

1980.passage:
you are too scrupulous, indeed you are," cried [MASK] warmly, and taking her hand. "You owe me no apologies; and every body to whom you might be supposed to owe them, is so perfectly satisfied, so delighted even--"

"You are very kind, but I know what my manners were to you.--So cold and artificial!--I had always a part to act.--It was a life of deceit!--I know that I must have disgusted you."

"Pray say no more.

1994.passage:
It will be the only difference."

"Poor child!" cried [MASK]; "at that rate, what will become of her?"

"Nothing very bad.--The fate of thousands.

1997.passage:
I, who am owing all my happiness to _you_, would not it be horrible ingratitude in me to be severe on them?"

[MASK] laughed, and replied: "But I had the assistance of all your endeavours to counteract the indulgence of other people. I doubt whether my own sense would have corrected me without it."

"Do you?--I have no doubt.

1999.passage:
I could not think about you so much without doating on you, faults and all; and by dint of fancying so many errors, have been in love with you ever since you were thirteen at least."

"I am sure you were of use to me," cried [MASK]. "I was very often influenced rightly by you--oftener than I would own at the time.

2012.passage:
But I am not afraid of your seeing what he writes."

"He writes like a sensible man," replied [MASK], when she had read the letter. "I honour his sincerity.

2046.passage:
Time, you may be sure, will make one or the other of us think differently; and, in the meanwhile, we need not talk much on the subject."

"You mistake me, you quite mistake me," [MASK] replied, exerting herself. "It is not that such a circumstance would now make me unhappy, but I cannot believe it.

2051.passage: Good God!" [MASK] cried.--"Well!"--Then having recourse to her workbasket, in excuse for leaning down her face, and concealing all the exquisite feelings of delight and entertainment which she knew she must be expressing, she added, "Well, now tell me every thing; make this intelligible to me. How, where, when?--Let me know it all.

2052.passage:
Good God!" she cried.--"Well!"--Then having recourse to her workbasket, in excuse for leaning down her face, and concealing all the exquisite feelings of delight and entertainment which she knew she must be expressing, [MASK] added, "Well, now tell me every thing; make this intelligible to me. How, where, when?--Let me know it all. I never was more surprized--but it does not make me unhappy, I assure you.--How--how has it been possible?"

"It is a very simple story.

2060.passage:
Do you dare say this?" cried [MASK]. "Do you dare to suppose me so great a blockhead, as not to know what a man is talking of?--What do you deserve?"

"Oh!

2075.passage:
I hope you do not retract what you then said."

"No, indeed," cried [MASK], most happy to begin, "not in the least. I am particularly glad to see and shake hands with you--and to give you joy in person."

He thanked her with all his heart, and continued some time to speak with serious feeling of his gratitude and happiness.

2080.passage:
I can never think of it," she cried, "without extreme shame."

"The shame," [MASK] answered, "is all mine, or ought to be. But is it possible that you had no suspicion?--I mean of late.

2094.passage:
Oh! no--what an impudent dog I was!--How could I dare--"

But he laughed so heartily at the recollection, that [MASK] could not help saying,

"I do suspect that in the midst of your perplexities at that time, you had very great amusement in tricking us all.--I am sure you had.--I am sure it was a consolation to you."

"Oh! no, no, no--how can you suspect me of such a thing?

2099.passage:
If not in our dispositions," she presently added, with a look of true sensibility, "there is a likeness in our destiny; the destiny which bids fair to connect us with two characters so much superior to our own."

"True, true," [MASK] answered, warmly. "No, not true on your side.
